description: A scene is a way of describing a page in your application including it's content, layout and style. The "render" field contains a list of elements to render.

name.description: The name of this scene. It should be in upper camel case.

render.description: A list of one or more elements to render. Each element refers to a built-in component (such as an Image).

styles.description: A list of style sets (each identified by name) which you can refer to within your render list above.

element.description: An element is a description of an item that will be rendered on screen. It must refer to a component (such as an Image or View) and it usually has additional properties such as style.

component.description: This refers to the name of a built-in component. It should be in upper camel case.

style.description: This property should be either a string (referring to the name of a style defined at the top level) or a set of key/value pairs describing the layout and styling of this element when it is rendered.

children.description: This is a list of zero or more elements that will be rendered inside this element.

style.description: A named list of styles, each of which is a set of key/value pairs describing the layout and styling of an element.

action.description: An action is an object that describes something the application should do (such as show a dialog). It must have the action name and optionally some other properties.
The name of the action. Often this will be of the form `controller/thing`
